misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculation instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the Euclidean distance between two points instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade. There is no variable representing a grade, no conditional logic for grade ranges, and the prompts refer to coordinates rather than a grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and print the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Input prompt asks for coordinates instead of a grade
Program reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
No conditional statements for grade ranges
Output message reports a distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or reuse of code from a different assignment (distance between two points) instead of implementing the requested grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required inputs (one numeric grade) and outputs (a letter grade). Start by reading a single number into a variable like 'grade', then use if/else-if statements to check which range it falls into and print the appropriate letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (prompts, variables, formula used, and output text) matches a standard distance-between-two-points problem and does not include any elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values, computes Euclidean distance, and prints it, which is unrelated to reading a grade and printing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implemented
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the distance between two points, a solution entirely unrelated to the requested task of writing a Grade Calculator. The code fails to implement any logic related to reading a numeric grade or determining a letter grade based on conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code intended for a different assignment (possibly a previous or concurrent task on calculating geometric distance).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The required program must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use if-else-if statements to map that grade to the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code prompts and reads four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2).
Code uses the Math.sqrt function and performs a distance calculation.
Output is labeled as 'The distance of the two points is...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Accidental submission of code written for a different problem, or a complete misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and submit the correct code that reads a single grade and uses conditional logic. The current submission is for a distance calculator.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is semantically correct for a geometric distance problem, but has no relation whatsoever to the required grade calculation problem. This is a definitive mismatch.

evidence.note: Reads four double values instead of a single numeric grade, demonstrating incorrect input handling for the required task.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance and prints the result, completely omitting the required conditional logic for grade determination.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Program Submitted / Task Confusion
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a Euclidean distance calculator program instead of a grade calculator program. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or a significant copy-paste/file submission error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should submit a program that calculates the distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a program that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges using conditional logic.
symptoms: Code reads 4 coordinate values instead of 1 grade
Code contains distance formula calculation instead of grade range checking
Output displays distance value instead of letter grade
Input prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of grade
No if/else conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread/misunderstood the assignment, submitted code from a different problem, or confused this assignment with another problem (possibly a coordinate geometry exercise).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read Q3 requirements. Start fresh with a new solution: (1) Read one grade value, (2) Use if/else statements to check if grade >= 90, then check >= 80, >= 70, >= 60, else F, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Single input reading vs. multiple inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously a distance calculator (uses distance formula, reads coordinates, outputs distance). There is no overlap with grade calculator requirements. This is not a misinterpretation but a complete mismatch.

evidence.note: Code reads 4 coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value (0-100)
Implements Euclidean distance formula instead of grade range checking logic

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Outputs distance value instead of letter grade (should output something like 'Letter grade: B')

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) instead of mapping a single numeric grade (0-100) to a letter grade A–F using conditional ranges. As a result, none of the required grade-calculator behavior (single grade input, range checks, letter output) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two coordinate points and computes the distance between them using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade (0-100) from the user and use conditional statements to determine which letter grade range it falls into: A (90–100), B (80–89), C (70–79), D (60–69), or F (below 60). It should then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates ("Enter x1 and y1:" and "Enter x2 and y2:") instead of a single grade.
Program reads four double values rather than one numeric grade.
Program computes sqrt((x2-x1)^2 + (y2-y1)^2) instead of any conditional logic.
Program outputs a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between exercises or reusing code from a different assignment involving the distance formula, combined with not carefully mapping the problem statement to the required input, processing, and output steps.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and restate it in your own words. Start by writing code to read exactly one numeric grade variable. Then add if-else chains to check which numeric range the grade falls into and print the correct letter. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems unless you clearly verify it matches the current requirements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is a standard distance-formula implementation and contains no grade-related variables, conditions, or outputs, so it clearly targets a different problem than the specified grade calculator.

evidence.note: Reads four doubles representing two coordinate points, not a single numeric grade as required by the grade calculator problem.

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Computes and prints the geometric distance between two points instead of using conditional logic to assign and print a letter grade.
Nowhere in main does the program read a grade, check numeric ranges, or output any letter grade, indicating a complete mismatch with the required algorithm.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points (a common introductory programming exercise) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) and applies the distance formula, completely failing to address the requirements of the grade calculation task, including input reading and conditional logic structure.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused the assignment with another common problem (Distance Formula) or copied an unrelated template, resulting in zero effort directed towards solving the required Grade Calculator task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt for and read a single numeric grade, and then use conditional logic (if/else if/else) to map that grade to the required letter grade ranges (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Incorrect input prompts ('Enter x1 and y1:', 'Enter x2 and y2:')
Code calculates distance instead of checking grade ranges
Uses Math.sqrt and multiplication instead of comparisons and if/else branching
All requirements of the prompt are unmet
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read/understand the problem statement and implement the required logic. Possible reasons include copying/pasting code from another exercise or profound confusion about the assigned task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully read the current problem statement and identify the necessary inputs and the core logical flow (conditional grading). Discard the current code and start fresh to implement the required if-else structure for grade mapping.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard (for the correct type)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The submitted code solves an entirely different mathematical problem (distance formula) using four input variables, confirming a complete divergence from the required assignment (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The code implements the distance formula and reads four coordinate inputs instead of a single grade input, demonstrating a complete misunderstanding of the task.

misconceptions.name: Submitted Code for Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted working code for a distance calculation problem instead of the grade calculator problem requested in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem (or has submitted the wrong file by mistake).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades to letters
Output displays distance instead of letter grades
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
No if-else statements checking grade thresholds (90, 80, 70, 60)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either submitted the wrong file, copied code from a different assignment, or fundamentally misunderstood which problem to solve.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the Q3 problem statement. Start fresh with code to: (1) prompt for and read one grade, (2) use if-else to check ranges, (3) output the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence—the code definitively calculates distance (Euclidean formula) with coordinates, not grades. This is objectively the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Student is reading four coordinate values instead of a single grade value.
This is the Euclidean distance formula: √[(x₂-x₁)² + (y₂-y₁)²]. It has nothing to do with grade calculation.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Output is a distance value, not a letter grade. Should output something like 'Letter grade: A'.
